paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: The paper discusses a heterozygous missense mutation A561V in the KCNH2 gene linked to long-QT syndrome type 2 (LQT2), with detailed functional studies and clinical implications.

patients.demographics: 1 male (18 years), 1 female (53 years), 1 male (57 years)

individual_records.phenotype_details: frequent episodes of syncope during physical or emotional stress
individual_records.evidence_sentence: The proband had presented with the main symptom of frequent episodes of syncope during physical or emotional stress over the past 13 years.
The mutation was not observed in the other family members.
The mutation was not observed in the other family members.

functional_data.summary: The A561V mutation exerts a dominant-negative effect on WT-hERG channels, leading to decreased hERG currents and impaired membrane localization.

variants.segregation_data: The A561V mutation segregated with the proband who exhibited severe clinical manifestations.
variants.population_frequency: not observed in 120 healthy control individuals
variants.evidence_level: strong evidence based on functional studies and clinical correlation
variants.additional_notes: The A561V mutation was linked to severe clinical manifestations of LQT2.
key_quotes: This mutation leads to substitution of the amino acid, alanine by valine (A561V) in the S5/pore region of the hERG protein.
This mutation was not observed in the 120 healthy control individuals.

extraction_metadata.notes: The extraction was straightforward as the relevant variant information was clearly presented in the text.
